fields.title: Three Cheese Hot Artichoke Dip
fields.description: This is a Paula Deen recipe, and as such it's as delicious as it is unhealthy.

fields.title: Neapolitan Pizza Dough
fields.description: A classic Neapolitan pizza dough that uses high-quality ingredients and a long fermentation period to develop a soft, delicious crust when baked at high temperatures.

fields.title: Basil Pesto
fields.description: A fresh-tasting sauce made from basil leaves that goes well with pasta, bread, tomatoes, and seafood.

fields.title: Brownie Cookies
fields.description: A small-batch recipe for gluten-free (but not sugar-free!) chocolate brownie cookies.

fields.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Drain and chop the artichoke hearts.
In a large mixing bowl, beat the cream cheese with an electric hand mixer until smooth.
Add the mayonnaise and beat until smooth.
Add the remaining ingredients and stir to combine.
Transfer the dip to a pie plate or shallow gratin dish.
Bake for 30 minutes or until the top is golden brown and the dip is bubbling.
Dissolve the yeast in the warm water and let sit for five minutes.
Add the water to the flour in a stand mixer bowl and combine roughly by hand.
Using a spiral dough hook, mix the flour and water in the stand mixer for five to ten minutes, gradually adding the salt as the dough homogenizes.
When the dough is mixed, remove it from the bowl and shape it into a large ball. Drizzle olive oil over the dough ball and rub it gently over the surface.
Place the dough ball in a 12 quart clear plastic tub with a lid and let rise at room temperature for twelve hours or until tripled in size.
Gently remove the dough from the plastic tub onto a clean working surface, taking care not to compress the dough. Using a dough knife, cut the dough into six equal-sized pieces.
Shape each piece into a tight ball. Coat the dough balls with flour and place in a plastic bag or airtight container. Let rise in the refrigerator for 24 to 48 hours.
Remove the dough from the refrigerator two hours before baking.

To shape the crust, generously flour both sides of a dough ball and place on a floured wooden pizza peel. Taking care not to disturb the outer edge or overstretch the center of the dough, gently stretch the dough apart with both hands, then rotate and repeat.
Bring a large pot of water to a vigorous boil, then blanche the basil leaves for thirty seconds. Immediately transfer them to a bowl of ice water.
Squeeze the basil leaves dry using paper towels, then combine all the ingredients in a food processor and blend on high speed until desired consistency is reached.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the powdered sugar, cocoa powder, and salt until combined. Make sure no clumps remain.
In another medium bowl, using an electric hand mixer on high speed, beat the egg whites and vanilla together until soft peaks form.
One half at a time, pour the solid mixture into the egg whites and gently fold together until moistened and incorporated, taking care not to overmix.
Gently mix in the chocolate chips.
Spoon the batter in ten to twelve equal sized portions onto a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper.
Bake for 17 minutes or until the tops of the cookies are dry and the edges have just begun to crack.
Remove from oven and let cool on the cookie sheet for five minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack.
